FSW.content: logo-phonocentrism is necessary and necessarily finite > history of the possibility of symbolism
FSW.linkedContent: logo-phonocentrism is necessary and necessarily finite > history of the possibility of symbolism

FSW.content: Freud: dream-interpreters were versed in symbolic riddling, a ground of interpretation giving the strongest credit to their Art
FSW.linkedContent: Freud: dream-interpreters were versed in symbolic riddling, a ground of interpretation giving the strongest credit to their Art

PPHS.content: Hegel: sign vs. symbol “symbol has identity w/ what it mimics, sign is foreign”
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel: sign vs. symbol “symbol has identity w/ what it mimics, sign is foreign”

PPHS.content: symbols (triangle, lion fox) possess the Bedeutung they’re expressing
PPHS.linkedContent: symbols (triangle, lion fox) possess the Bedeutung they’re expressing

PPHS.content: despite symbol’s identity, sign’s arbitrariness is closer to independence, freedom of spirt than external, natural symbol [Saussure concurs in footnotes]
PPHS.linkedContent: despite symbol’s identity, sign’s arbitrariness is closer to independence, freedom of spirt than external, natural symbol [Saussure concurs in footnotes]

PPHS.content: sign is essence of symbol, the symbol past, both in turn relevé by living concept, language w/out language, language become thing itself, voice murmuring in greatest proximity to spirit, identity of the name, of Being
PPHS.linkedContent: sign is essence of symbol, the symbol past, both in turn relevé by living concept, language w/out language, language become thing itself, voice murmuring in greatest proximity to spirit, identity of the name, of Being

F.content: Freud: symbol always symbol of an earlier symbolized, and Torok and Abraham examine symbol’s operative genesis, as a hieroglyph, so it never becomes a “dead symbol,” a substance
F.linkedContent: Freud: symbol always symbol of an earlier symbolized, and Torok and Abraham examine symbol’s operative genesis, as a hieroglyph, so it never becomes a “dead symbol,” a substance

F.content: Abraham: symbol to semantic might just be symbol to symbol; what we most seek is to place symbol back into dynamism of intersubjective functioning
F.linkedContent: Abraham: symbol to semantic might just be symbol to symbol; what we most seek is to place symbol back into dynamism of intersubjective functioning

F.content: cryptonomy: crack (la ligne de brisure) of a symbol, upright column of name (colonne érigée d’un nom), blank voice of a scruple [see p. xiii], always extends beyond the self
F.linkedContent: cryptonomy: crack (la ligne de brisure) of a symbol, upright column of name (colonne érigée d’un nom), blank voice of a scruple [see p. xiii], always extends beyond the self

F.content: Wolf Man calls himself by unspeakable name Thing (tieret), gives himself no name > entire body of a proper name always shattered (morcelé) by the topoi, la Chose est un morceau de symbole
F.linkedContent: Wolf Man calls himself by unspeakable name Thing (tieret), gives himself no name > entire body of a proper name always shattered (morcelé) by the topoi, la Chose est un morceau de symbole

WM.content: Marx on gold serving as symbol of itself, and that “nothing can serve as symbol of itself”
WM.linkedContent: Marx on gold serving as symbol of itself, and that “nothing can serve as symbol of itself”

P.content: Kant looking for a bridge from sensible to supersensible (an analogy), a symbol—that crosses/closes abyss
P.linkedContent: Kant looking for a bridge from sensible to supersensible (an analogy), a symbol—that crosses/closes abyss

P.content: bridge (Brücke) not an analogy, concept/effect of analogy makes the bridge itself
P.linkedContent: bridge (Brücke) not an analogy, concept/effect of analogy makes the bridge itself

P.content: analogy of abyss & bridge over abyss require 3rd term, that which heals the gap, a symbol, bridge is symbol, symbol bridge > abyss calls for analogy (active resource of Critique), mais l’analogie s’abîme sans fin dès lors qu’il faut bien un certain art pour décrire analogiquement le jeu de l’analogie
P.linkedContent: analogy of abyss & bridge over abyss require 3rd term, that which heals the gap, a symbol, bridge is symbol, symbol bridge > abyss calls for analogy (active resource of Critique), mais l’analogie s’abîme sans fin dès lors qu’il faut bien un certain art pour décrire analogiquement le jeu de l’analogie

P.content: w/ sublime, everything that is compared to it is small > here, Kant throws a bridge, the bridge like the symbol throws itself [by way of reason?], btwn unpresentable and presentation > the whole world can be made small in relation to sublime magnitude
P.linkedContent: w/ sublime, everything that is compared to it is small > here, Kant throws a bridge, the bridge like the symbol throws itself [by way of reason?], btwn unpresentable and presentation > the whole world can be made small in relation to sublime magnitude

REST.content: whose shoes (whose feet) (the subject of reattachment): the capital subject of this contract [btwn Shapiro & Heidegger], they each have one piece of symbolon, share common interest, coded commitment
REST.linkedContent: whose shoes (whose feet) (the subject of reattachment): the capital subject of this contract [btwn Shapiro & Heidegger], they each have one piece of symbolon, share common interest, coded commitment

C.content: breakable, limping hyphen: not only an emblem, a coat of arms, but the symbol > acc. symballein, brings together pieces of a body divided in contract, pact, alliance [symballistic]
C.linkedContent: breakable, limping hyphen: not only an emblem, a coat of arms, but the symbol > acc. symballein, brings together pieces of a body divided in contract, pact, alliance [symballistic]
